article:
I read a piece of news today that the richest people were paying 736, 000 dollars for watches at present. As I was   _   my head at their craziness, I glanced at my own 8-dollar watch. It told me the time just fine. I guessed that about 735, 992 dollars were   left over   from buying such a cheap watch. With that I could send 18 kids to college for four years each with the room, board, and books included. With that I could sponsor   _   200 needy children overseas into adulthood. With that I could buy   _   for 2.5 million starving people around the world. With that money I could do so much good, help so many souls, and still know the   _   whenever I looked down at my wrist.
When did our society become so   _   that anyone would think they needed a 736, 000-dollar watch? When did people become so   _   that they would believe a one-million-dollar   _   is essential? My first car cost me only 500 dollars and it still gets me where I need to go. When did 50-million-dollar yachts   and 100-million-dollar houses become so  _   to a person's happiness? My tiny home has more 25 _  in it than the biggest mansion in the world and I can walk on the shore of the local lake here and   _   its beauty for free.
I pray that at some point our society says "Enough!" and   wakes up   from this horrible dream of materialism. Each of us only has one life. Let's not   _   it on the watches we wear and the cars we drive. Each of us only has one soul. Let's not   _   it trying to gain the whole world. Life puts us here to love each other and to make this world a better place. Help others whenever you can. Life is brief and no watch will sell a(n)  _   second of it to you.
